awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation award supports research to develop new tools to study three- and four-dimensional spaces as well as knotted curves, bringing together techniques from many mathematical disciplines. As these objects closely relate to our physical world and the space-time, this line of research is partially inspired by modern physics. As such, it lies at a fertile intellectual crossroads, bringing new perspectives to neighboring subjects, and providing novel methods for attacking old problems. The PI and his collaborators pioneered new invariants, known as "Heegaard-Floer homology" and "knot Floer homology," and developed a technique known as "bordered Floer homology" for effectively utilizing simple component pieces of a space. Research funded by this award deals with further developing these bordered techniques for three-dimensional spaces and for knotted curves, to get both a better conceptual understanding of these invariants, and for giving effective computational techniques for studying them.

In collaboration with Zoltan Szabo, the PI constructed an invariant for three- and four-dimensional spaces known as the "Heegaard-Floer homology." Heegaard-Floer homology brings together tools from various mathematical disciplines, including symplectic geometry, analysis, and homological algebra, to study problems in knot theory and low-dimensional topology, in a way that was partially inspired by modern physics. A variant of this construction, called "knot Floer homology," is used to study knots in three-dimensional manifolds. In collaboration with Robert Lipshitz and Dylan Thurston, the PI defined "bordered Floer homology," a technique for reconstructing one variant of Heegaard-Floer homology from a three-manifold that is decomposed into simple component pieces. In the research funded by this award, the PI aims to study bordered Floer homology as a tool for studying various versions of Heegaard-Floer homology and knot Floer homology.  Part of the project will start by extending the bordered theory to include the full (unspecialized) Heegaard-Floer homology for three-manifolds with torus boundary. In a different direction, bordered Floer homology is extended to a tool for studying and computing knot Floer homology.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Knotted closed loops in three-dimensional space are fundamental objects of study. They are of intrinsic interest to mathematicians, but questions about them have arisen in other fields, including physics and biology. The serious mathematical study of knots dates back to the 18th century. A rigorous approach to these objects was pioneered by the great mathematician Carl Friedrich Gauss in the 19th century; and the modern foundations of ``knot theory?? were laid by topologists from the beginning of the 20th century. A key approach is to associate auxiliary mathematical objects, called knot invariants, to knotted loops -- these knot invariants can be  as simple as numbers; or they can be more sophisticated, such as polynomial functions in an auxiliary variable; or indeed they can be far more sophisticated algebraic objects. To this day, progress in knot theory has served as a benchmark for our understanding of mathematics.

The intense interaction between mathematics and modern physics in the 1980's and 1990's resulted in a new mathematical perspective, called Floer homology, named after its discoverer, Andreas Floer. Since the work of Floer, a number of new versions of Floer homology have been defined in many different mathematical contexts.

Around 2000, the Principal Investigator of this grant, in collaboration with Zolt?n Szab? defined a version of Floer homology for three-dimensional spaces, called Heegaard Floer homology, which they, and independently Jacob Rasmussen, extended to the case of knots in three-space. The resulting (Heegaard-Floer) knot Floor homology provides a new tool for studying classical questions and problems about knots. However, the original construction of this invariant was indirect, and explicit computations for concrete knots was challenging.

A topological invariant should be computable by disassembling the space which is studied, associating data to the constituent pieces, and then providing a framework for assembling the invariant out the invariants associated to the simpler pieces.  Around 2008, the PI, in collaboration with Robert Lipshitz and Dylan Thurston, defined exactly such a computational scheme for a simplified version of Heegaard Floer homology. The resulting theory, bordered Floer homology, has provided a model for further computational progress.

The project at hand applied the philosophy of bordered Floer homology to make knot Floer homology computationally tractable. Specifically, given a combinatorial representation for a knot (in the form of a picture of the knot), the work from the proposal produces an explicit algorithm which can be implemented on a computer for computing knot Floer homology. It also lays foundations for defining bordered Floer homology in other contexts.

Intellectual Merit: This project provides new, concrete tools for understanding classical questions and challenges in knot theory. The bordered theory lies at a fruitful crossroads of different mathematical disciplines, including mathematical analysis, abstract algebra, topology, and geometry, with an infusion of ideas from physics. As such, progress in this field sheds light on all of these subjects, in addition to supplying new information about the underlying objects of study: knots and more general three-dimensional spaces. 

Broader Impact: Although aspects of Floer homology can be quite arcane, the combinatorial knot Floer homology studied in this proposal are quite accessible to students, including motivated undergraduates. The methods also provide a host of new tools for studying old problems which have eluded solution, making the field quite attractive to the next generation of mathematicians. In addition to laying these foundations and providing data from computer calculations of topological invariants, the project also helped fund the training of undergraduates (many of whom went on to pursue graduate studies), graduate students (who typically go on to postdoctoral programs), and postdoctoral fellows (who typically go on to more senior positions, where they help provide the mathematical training for students who are interested in a wide variety of fields which require a mathematical background). 

 


Last Modified: 09/21/2021
Modified by: Peter S Ozsvath
